Lights Out

Click on any light to toggle it and its neighbors. Turn all lights off to win!

Addendum: Development Process

Creative Choices:

  • Used a 5x5 grid as the classic Lights Out configuration
  • Implemented a yellow "on" state and dark gray "off" state for clear visual distinction
  • Added smooth transitions for a polished user experience
  • Used Times New Roman font for a classic, readable appearance

Technical Implementation:

  • Created a solvable random board by starting with all lights off and simulating random clicks
  • Used the "is-off" class system to manage light states efficiently
  • Implemented neighbor-toggling logic using row/column calculations
  • Added win detection that checks if all squares have the "is-off" class

Challenges & Solutions:

  • Challenge: Ensuring the board is always solvable
    Solution: Started with a solved state (all off) and simulated 20-30 random moves
  • Challenge: Managing the toggling of neighbors correctly
    Solution: Created a helper function that calculates valid neighbor positions and toggles them
  • Challenge: Preventing multiple win alerts during the checking process
    Solution: Used a setTimeout to delay the win check, allowing animations to complete

Insights Gained:

This project reinforced the importance of state management in game development. The key insight was that by reversing the problem (starting solved and working backwards), we could guarantee solvability. I also learned that small UX details like transition delays and visual feedback significantly improve the player experience.
